Another Goodbye https://wordsinspace.net/2022/03/02/another-goodbye/ Wed, 02 Mar 2022 21:19:56 +0000 Blog,dogs Today we said goodbye to another four-legged friend. Lily succumbed to a brain tumor that manifested very quickly, incited some violent seizures, and robbed her of her balance, her mobility, and her delight in all of her favorite things. It was all too soon. Lily joins Pippi, Dugan, Roxy, Rudy, Dexter, and Opie, who preceded […]

Today we said goodbye to another four-legged friend. Lily succumbed to a brain tumor that manifested very quickly, incited some violent seizures, and robbed her of her balance, her mobility, and her delight in all of her favorite things. It was all too soon.

Lily joins Pippi, Dugan, Roxy, Rudy, Dexter, and Opie, who preceded her into the hereafter. Lily came to us in the summer of 2015 after spending the first year of her life as a scarred, mange-afflicted stray puppy who then lucked into the care of a wonderful rescue organization. She was covered with freckles, and it took several years — with frequent therapeutic baths — for her hair to grow in.

She grew into a big, powerful dog, yet she was so gentle. A couple years ago we (okay, I) took in a stray kitten, and Lily took to Pip immediately. They became close friends.

Dugan passed away just a few months after Lily came along, but she then became a wonderful — if occasionally intimidating — big sister to Elliott and Duncan. Ellie has a little trouble sharing, yet Lily always gently nudged him toward generosity

She loved frisbee and her two couches, where she often loved to sleep with her head — or her whole body — on your lap. Sometimes, she’d plant her two front feet on my dad’s shoulders, a sign that she wanted a belly rub.

She also loved sitting on my mom’s bed, in the sun, looking out over the field.

She and my mom were especially close.

I’ll miss her big wet nose, her Flying Nun ears, her big paws with the multicolored nails…

…and that big lightning-speed tongue that gave so many stealthy kisses.

We’ll miss you, baby girl, but we’ll never forget you. We wish you were able to stay with us longer — but we’re so glad you had eight full, vibrant years, during which you brought so much love and happiness to those with whom you shared your life. May your future days be filled with sunny days, green lawns, frisbees, endless belly rubs, and lots of love. I hope you’ll always feel our love from here on the other side.

Redesigning the Academy https://wordsinspace.net/2022/01/23/redesigning-the-academy/ Sun, 23 Jan 2022 08:37:52 +0000 Classes,Academia,pedagogy Graduate Elective In this workshop, part of the Anthropology + Design graduate minor (although open to all graduate students), we integrate critical university studies, educational anthropology, decolonizing movements, theories and methods of radical pedagogy, histories of alternative schools, and art and design work committed to institutional and pedagogical critique in order to assess the state […]

Graduate Elective

In this workshop, part of the Anthropology + Design graduate minor (although open to all graduate students), we integrate critical university studies, educational anthropology, decolonizing movements, theories and methods of radical pedagogy, histories of alternative schools, and art and design work committed to institutional and pedagogical critique in order to assess the state of the American academy and imagine it otherwise. As we interrogate everything from learning architectures and evaluation systems to admissions and publishing models, we’ll engage in seminar discussions, design workshops, fieldwork exercises, and field trips; host guest speakers; and, depending upon the luck of course planning, potentially collaborate with parallel projects at other institutions. Students will create speculative syllabi and curricula; compose manifestos and critical pitch decks, and design other pedagogical materials and epistemological infrastructures.

Spring 2022 Class Website

Archiving Forensic Material https://wordsinspace.net/2021/11/14/archivingforensicmaterial/ Sun, 14 Nov 2021 20:58:59 +0000 Presentations,Archives,Forensics,materiality On November 15, 2021, I spoke with Brad Samuels’s “Visual Investigations of Power and Protest” class at the Cooper Union. I focused on the archival demands and challenges of using photogrammetry, 3D modeling and other data-intensive techniques to model human rights abuses and protests. Image via ICD, public domain

On November 15, 2021, I spoke with Brad Samuels’s “Visual Investigations of Power and Protest” class at the Cooper Union. I focused on the archival demands and challenges of using photogrammetry, 3D modeling and other data-intensive techniques to model human rights abuses and protests.

Image via ICD, public domain

Images (all cited within the article): From a ca. 1505 edition of Arbor Scientiae by Ramon Llull. [via Wikipedia, public domain]; The Garden of Eden with the Fall of Man, oil painting by Peter Paul Rubens (figures) and Jan Brueghel the Elder (landscape), ca. 1615. [Mauritshis, The Hague, via Wikimedia, public domain]; Tree rings, species unidentified. [Arpingston via Wikimedia, public domain]; Left: A fragment of the Heracles Papyrus, ca. 3rd century.
